turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about History of the Shakespeare authorship question.
turn.1: What are the main points in the history of the Shakespeare authorship question?
turn.2: At the same time scholars were increasingly becoming aware that many plays were collaborations, and that now-lost plays may have served as models for Shakespeare's published work, such as, for example, the "ur-Hamlet", an earlier version of Shakespeare's play of that name.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In Benjamin Disraeli's novel "Venetia" (1837) the character Lord Cadurcis, modelled on Byron, questions whether Shakespeare wrote "half of the plays attributed to him", or even one "whole play" but rather that he was "an inspired adapter for the theatres".
turn.5: Was there any controversy on this?
turn.6: A similar view was expressed by an American lawyer and writer, Col.
turn.7: Did anyone else question his writings?
turn.8: Joseph C. Hart, who in 1848 published "The Romance of Yachting", which for the first time asserted explicitly and unequivocally in print that Shakespeare did not write the works bearing his name.
turn.9: What did Shakespeare have to say about this?
turn.10: Hart claimed that Shakespeare was a "mere "factotum" of the theatre", a "vulgar and unlettered man" hired to add obscene jokes to the plays of other writers.
turn.11: Did anyone else question his writings?
turn.12: Hart does not suggest that there was any conspiracy, merely that evidence of the real authors's identities had been lost when the plays were published.
